reasons.kritis: As an operator of critical infrastructure (KRITIS), you are classified as an essential entity regardless of company size.
reasons.alwaysQualified: Your business area (qualified trust service provider, DNS service provider, or TLD registry) falls under essential entities regardless of company size.
reasons.anlage1LargeEntity: Your company meets the size thresholds for essential entities: at least 250 employees OR annual revenue exceeding €50 million and balance sheet exceeding €43 million.
reasons.standardThreshold: Your company meets the thresholds for important entities: at least 50 employees OR annual revenue exceeding €10 million and balance sheet exceeding €10 million.
reasons.belowThreshold: Your company is below the NIS2 thresholds (less than 50 employees AND annual revenue/balance sheet below €10 million). You are likely not directly affected by NIS2.
reasons.sectorNotRegulated: Your sector is not included in the NIS2-regulated sectors of Annexes 1 and 2 to BSIG.

classification.supplychainHint: Note: Even if you are not directly affected by NIS2, your customers or clients may impose security requirements on you as a supplier if they are NIS2-regulated entities (Art. 21(2)(d), §30(2)(4) BSIG).

raQ1.title: Do you have a current overview of your IT risks (e.g., which systems are critical, where vulnerabilities exist)?
raQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires regular risk analyses (Art. 21(2)(a), §30 Para. 2 No. 1 BSIG). BSI recommends the methodology from BSI Standard 200-3.

maturity.level1: Rough assessment available but not documented
maturity.level2: Documented risk analysis but not regularly updated
maturity.level3: Regular, documented risk analysis following a recognized standard

raQ2.title: Are your IT security measures documented in writing and regularly updated?
raQ2.tooltip: Documented security concepts are the foundation for demonstrable compliance (§30 Para. 1 BSIG). See BSI building block ISMS.1.

maturity.level1: Partially documented but outdated
maturity.level2: Largely documented but not regularly updated
maturity.level3: Fully documented and updated at least annually

raQ3.title: Have you established clear responsibilities for IT security (e.g., designated contact person)?
raQ3.tooltip: NIS2 requires management accountability (§38 BSIG). Clear responsibilities are the foundation for effective security management.

maturity.level1: Informally assigned, not documented
maturity.level2: Documented but not known to all employees
maturity.level3: Clearly documented, communicated, with deputy arrangements

ihQ1.title: Is there an established procedure for how your company responds to cyberattacks or IT disruptions?
ihQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires documented incident response processes (Art. 21(2)(b), §30 Para. 2 No. 2 BSIG). See BSI building block DER.2.1.

maturity.level1: Ad-hoc response without fixed procedure
maturity.level2: Basic procedure documented but not regularly practiced
maturity.level3: Documented procedure with regular exercises and clear roles

ihQ2.title: Do you have emergency contact details (e.g., BSI reporting office, IT service providers) readily available?
ihQ2.tooltip: NIS2 prescribes reporting obligations (§32 BSIG). Quick response requires prepared contact lists and reporting channels.

maturity.level1: Some contacts known but not centrally available
maturity.level2: Contact list exists but not regularly updated
maturity.level3: Current contact list centrally available, including BSI reporting channels

ihQ3.title: Are security incidents logged and evaluated to learn from them?
ihQ3.tooltip: Learning from incidents is essential for improving security. See BSI building blocks DER.2.1 and OPS.1.1.5 (Logging).

maturity.level1: Incidents partially recorded but not systematically evaluated
maturity.level2: Systematic recording but no regular evaluation
maturity.level3: Complete recording, regular evaluation, and documented improvements

bcQ1.title: Do you regularly create backups of your important data and test them?
bcQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires backup management and recovery capability (Art. 21(2)(c), §30 Para. 2 No. 3 BSIG). See BSI building block CON.3.

maturity.level1: Backups created but not tested
maturity.level2: Regular backups with occasional recovery tests
maturity.level3: Automated backups with regularly tested recovery

bcQ2.title: Can you resume operations within 24-48 hours after a severe IT outage?
bcQ2.tooltip: Recovery capability is a core NIS2 objective. BSI Standard 200-4 describes Business Continuity Management (BCM).

maturity.level1: General idea but no documented plan
maturity.level2: Recovery plan exists but not tested
maturity.level3: Documented and regularly tested recovery plan

bcQ3.title: Do you have a written emergency plan for cyberattacks or system failures?
bcQ3.tooltip: Crisis management requires prepared emergency plans (§30 Para. 2 No. 3 BSIG). See BSI building block DER.4 (Emergency Management).

maturity.level1: Informal knowledge with individual persons
maturity.level2: Written plan available but not known to all
maturity.level3: Documented plan, known to all and regularly practiced

scQ1.title: Do you assess the IT security of your most important suppliers and service providers?
scQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires assessment of direct suppliers' and service providers' security (Art. 21(2)(d), §30 Para. 2 No. 4 BSIG). Particularly important for cloud services and IT outsourcing.

maturity.level1: Occasional informal inquiry
maturity.level2: Key suppliers assessed but not systematically
maturity.level3: Systematic assessment of all critical suppliers with documented results

scQ2.title: Do you have contractual IT security agreements with your IT service providers?
scQ2.tooltip: Contractual security requirements for service providers are an essential part of NIS2 supply chain security.

maturity.level1: General terms, no specific security clauses
maturity.level2: Security clauses with key service providers
maturity.level3: Standardized security requirements in all IT service provider contracts

scQ3.title: Do you know which external service providers have access to your critical systems or data?
scQ3.tooltip: Transparency about external access is a prerequisite for effective supply chain security. See BSI building block ORP.1.

maturity.level1: Partial overview, not documented
maturity.level2: Documented overview but not regularly updated
maturity.level3: Complete, current overview with regular review

adQ1.title: Are security updates for your IT systems applied promptly?
adQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires vulnerability management (Art. 21(2)(e), §30 Para. 2 No. 5 BSIG). Timely patching is one of the most important protective measures. See BSI building block OPS.1.1.3.

maturity.level1: Updates applied occasionally without fixed process
maturity.level2: Regular updates on schedule but not comprehensive
maturity.level3: Systematic patch management with prioritization and tracking

adQ2.title: Do you consider IT security aspects when purchasing or developing new software?
adQ2.tooltip: NIS2 requires security-by-design (Art. 21(2)(e), §30 Para. 2 No. 5 BSIG). Security must be considered from the start. See BSI building block CON.8.

maturity.level1: Occasionally considered but no fixed process
maturity.level2: Security criteria for major acquisitions but not standardized
maturity.level3: Standardized security assessment for all IT acquisitions and developments

adQ3.title: Do you have a process to identify and fix vulnerabilities in your software?
adQ3.tooltip: Vulnerability management and disclosure are explicit NIS2 requirements (§30 Para. 2 No. 5 BSIG).

maturity.level1: Vulnerabilities handled ad-hoc
maturity.level2: Basic process in place but not all systems covered
maturity.level3: Systematic vulnerability management with scanning and prioritization

eaQ1.title: Do you regularly verify whether your security measures actually work (e.g., through audits)?
eaQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires regular effectiveness assessment (Art. 21(2)(f), §30 Para. 2 No. 6 BSIG). See BSI building block ISMS.1.

maturity.level1: Occasional informal review
maturity.level2: Regular review of individual measures
maturity.level3: Systematic audits of all security measures with documented results

eaQ2.title: Do you conduct security tests (e.g., penetration tests or vulnerability scans)?
eaQ2.tooltip: Technical tests are an important part of effectiveness assessment. They reveal vulnerabilities not visible in theory.

maturity.level1: Occasional tests when specific need arises
maturity.level2: Regular vulnerability scans but no penetration tests
maturity.level3: Regular penetration tests and vulnerability scans with follow-up

eaQ3.title: Are concrete improvement actions derived and implemented from security reviews?
eaQ3.tooltip: The PDCA cycle (Plan-Do-Check-Act) is at the core of continuous improvement. See BSI building block ORP.5 (Compliance Management).

maturity.level1: Improvements identified but not systematically implemented
maturity.level2: Improvements documented and partially implemented
maturity.level3: Systematic improvement process with tracking and effectiveness control

chQ1.title: Are your employees regularly trained on IT security topics (e.g., recognizing phishing)?
chQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires basic training (Art. 21(2)(g), §30 Para. 2 No. 7 BSIG). See BSI building block ORP.3.

maturity.level1: One-time or occasional advice
maturity.level2: Annual training but not reaching all employees
maturity.level3: Regular training for all employees with effectiveness verification

chQ2.title: Are there clear guidelines for secure behavior (e.g., password rules, handling emails)?
chQ2.tooltip: Cyber hygiene guidelines define minimum standards for secure work. They form the basis for training and awareness.

maturity.level1: Informal rules, not written down
maturity.level2: Written guidelines available but not known to all
maturity.level3: Current guidelines known to all employees and regularly reviewed

chQ3.title: Are new employees systematically introduced to IT security topics?
chQ3.tooltip: Security onboarding ensures new employees act security-consciously from the start. See BSI building block ORP.2.

maturity.level1: Occasional verbal advice
maturity.level2: Standardized introduction but not documented
maturity.level3: Documented security introduction as a fixed part of onboarding

crQ1.title: Are confidential data encrypted during storage and transmission (e.g., via HTTPS, VPN)?
crQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires the use of cryptographic measures (Art. 21(2)(h), §30 Para. 2 No. 8 BSIG). See BSI building block CON.1.

maturity.level1: Partial encryption (e.g., HTTPS for website only)
maturity.level2: Encryption for most sensitive data but gaps exist
maturity.level3: Comprehensive encryption of all sensitive data at rest and in transit

crQ2.title: Do you have a concept for which data must be encrypted and with which methods?
crQ2.tooltip: A cryptography concept defines where encryption is used and which algorithms/key lengths are applied. See BSI building block CON.1.

maturity.level1: Encryption used ad-hoc without concept
maturity.level2: Basic concept available but not fully implemented
maturity.level3: Documented cryptography concept with current methods and regular review

crQ3.title: Are cryptographic keys managed securely (e.g., not stored in plain text)?
crQ3.tooltip: Key management is critical: compromised keys render encryption worthless. Secure storage and regular rotation are essential.

maturity.level1: Keys stored without special protection
maturity.level2: Basic protection measures but no systematic management
maturity.level3: Systematic key management with secure storage and rotation

acQ1.title: Do only authorized persons have access to critical IT systems and data?
acQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires access control following the principle of least privilege (Art. 21(2)(i), §30 Para. 2 No. 9 BSIG). See BSI building block ORP.4.

maturity.level1: Basic access restrictions but no differentiated rights
maturity.level2: Role-based access rights for important systems
maturity.level3: Comprehensive access control with least-privilege principle and regular review

acQ2.title: Are access rights regularly reviewed and immediately revoked when employees leave?
acQ2.tooltip: Outdated access rights are a common security risk. Regular review prevents unauthorized access.

maturity.level0: No review, old rights remain active
maturity.level1: Rights revoked on departure but no regular review
maturity.level2: Regular review but not all systems covered
maturity.level3: Systematic rights review across all systems with immediate revocation on departure

acQ3.title: Are physical access controls in place for critical IT areas (e.g., server room)?
acQ3.tooltip: Physical protection of critical IT infrastructure is part of access control. See BSI building blocks INF.1 (Building) and INF.2 (Data Center).

maturity.level1: Server room locked but no access log
maturity.level2: Access control with key/card but no logging
maturity.level3: Electronic access control with logging and regular review

mcQ1.title: Do you use multi-factor authentication (e.g., authenticator app, hardware token) for critical systems?
mcQ1.tooltip: NIS2 requires MFA for privileged access (Art. 21(2)(j), §30 Para. 2 No. 10 BSIG). MFA protects against password theft and unauthorized access.

maturity.level1: MFA for individual systems (e.g., cloud email only)
maturity.level2: MFA for most critical systems
maturity.level3: MFA for all critical systems and privileged access

mcQ2.title: Is confidential communication encrypted (e.g., encrypted emails, secure video conferences)?
mcQ2.tooltip: Secured communication protects against eavesdropping and manipulation. NIS2 requires secured voice, video and text communication (§30 Para. 2 No. 10 BSIG).

maturity.level1: Partially encrypted (e.g., internal chats only)
maturity.level2: Encrypted communication for most sensitive topics
maturity.level3: Comprehensive encrypted communication for all confidential content

mcQ3.title: Do you have secure communication channels for emergencies (e.g., alternative channels during IT outage)?
mcQ3.tooltip: Secured emergency communication ensures your crisis team remains reachable even during IT outages (§30 Para. 2 No. 10 BSIG).

maturity.level1: Personal phone numbers as informal emergency channel
maturity.level2: Defined emergency channel but not tested
maturity.level3: Tested emergency communication with secure, independent channels

check.title: NIS2 Affected Check
check.subtitle: Check in a few steps whether your company is affected by NIS2

sectorStep.title: In which sector does your company operate?

sizeStep.title: How large is your company?
sizeStep.balanceSheetTooltip: If known, please provide. If not, only revenue will be used for classification.
sizeStep.kritisTooltip: KRITIS operators are classified as particularly important entities regardless of company size (Sec. 28(1)(1) BSIG). This applies to e.g. energy suppliers, large water utilities, or hospitals.
sizeStep.employeesRequired: Please enter the number of employees

resultStep.title: Your Result
resultStep.supplyChainText: Even if you are not directly affected by NIS2, your customers or clients as NIS2-regulated entities may impose security requirements on you as a supplier (Art. 21(2)(d), Sec. 30(2)(4) BSIG).

ra1.title: Create an IT Risk Inventory
ra1.description: Systematically identify all critical IT systems, data, and processes along with their threats.
ra1.firstStep: List your 5 most important IT systems and assess their criticality for business operations.

ra2.title: Define Security Responsibilities
ra2.description: Appoint an IT security officer and document responsibilities and reporting lines.
ra2.firstStep: Designate a responsible person for IT security and communicate this to all employees.

ih1.title: Create an Incident Response Plan
ih1.description: Create a documented plan for responding to security incidents with clear roles and procedures.
ih1.firstStep: Define the 3 most common incident scenarios (e.g., ransomware, phishing, data loss) and describe initial response steps.

ih2.title: Compile Emergency Contacts
ih2.description: Create a current contact list with internal contacts, external IT service providers, and BSI reporting channels.
ih2.firstStep: Collect your IT service provider's contact details and learn about the BSI reporting obligation (meldestelle@bsi.bund.de).

bc1.title: Implement a Backup Strategy
bc1.description: Implement a 3-2-1 backup strategy: 3 copies, 2 media types, 1 offsite. Regularly test recovery.
bc1.firstStep: Check if automatic backups are set up for your most important data and test a recovery.

bc2.title: Create an Emergency Plan
bc2.description: Create an IT emergency plan with recovery priorities, responsibilities, and communication channels.
bc2.firstStep: Identify your 5 most important business processes and define their maximum tolerable downtime.

sc1.title: Create a Supplier Overview
sc1.description: Document all external IT service providers and their access to your systems and data.
sc1.firstStep: Create a list of all external service providers that have access to your IT systems or data.

sc2.title: Add Security Clauses to Contracts
sc2.description: Add security requirements and audit rights to IT service provider contracts.
sc2.firstStep: Review your most important IT service provider contract for existing security clauses.

ad1.title: Implement Patch Management
ad1.description: Establish a process for timely application of security updates across all systems.
ad1.firstStep: Enable automatic OS updates and create a list of all software in use.

ad2.title: Security Assessment for Acquisitions
ad2.description: Integrate security criteria into the procurement process for new IT systems and software.
ad2.firstStep: Create a checklist with security criteria (encryption, update frequency, vendor support) for IT procurements.

ea1.title: Introduce Regular Security Reviews
ea1.description: Plan at least annual reviews of your security measures, internally or through external auditors.
ea1.firstStep: Schedule a first review of your most important security measures within the next 3 months.

ea2.title: Conduct Vulnerability Scans
ea2.description: Perform regular technical security tests to identify vulnerabilities early.
ea2.firstStep: Research free vulnerability scanners (e.g., OpenVAS) or commission an external penetration test.

ch1.title: Start an Awareness Training Program
ch1.description: Introduce regular IT security training for all employees, at least annually.
ch1.firstStep: Organize a first training session on phishing recognition for all employees.

ch2.title: Document Security Guidelines
ch2.description: Create understandable guidelines for passwords, email security, mobile devices, and remote work.
ch2.firstStep: Write a one-page password policy (minimum length, complexity, no reuse).

cr1.title: Implement Encryption Standards
cr1.description: Ensure all sensitive data is encrypted during storage and transmission.
cr1.firstStep: Check if your website uses HTTPS and if emails with sensitive content are sent encrypted.

cr2.title: Create a Cryptography Concept
cr2.description: Document where encryption is used, which methods and key lengths you employ.
cr2.firstStep: Create an overview of all places where encryption is or should be used.

ac1.title: Implement Role-Based Access Control
ac1.description: Implement the principle of least privilege: every employee receives only the rights needed for their role.
ac1.firstStep: Review admin rights: which employees have administrator access and do they really need it?

ac2.title: Offboarding Process for IT Access
ac2.description: Ensure all IT access is immediately deactivated when employees leave.
ac2.firstStep: Create a checklist of all systems and access that must be deactivated when an employee departs.

mc1.title: Activate MFA for Critical Systems
mc1.description: Enable multi-factor authentication for all critical systems, starting with email and VPN.
mc1.firstStep: Enable MFA for your business email (Microsoft 365, Google Workspace) and document the setup.

mc2.title: Set Up Secure Communication Channels
mc2.description: Provide encrypted communication channels for confidential business content and emergencies.
mc2.firstStep: Set up an encrypted messenger (e.g., Signal) as emergency communication channel and share contacts with the crisis team.
